subject: MORAY-418 moray should queue requests when new PG connections fail MORAY-339 moray needs to use exponential backoff when connection to postgresql MORAY-294 suspect moray doesn't honor its connection limit properly MORAY-427 moray queuing needs work
commitMessage:
MORAY-418 moray should queue requests when new PG connections fail
MORAY-339 moray needs to use exponential backoff when connection to postgresql
MORAY-294 suspect moray doesn't honor its connection limit properly
MORAY-427 moray queuing needs work

"make check" exited with status 2

 /tmp/repo/build/node/bin/node node_modules/.bin/eslint  main.js lib/control.js lib/manatee.js lib/schema.js lib/buckets/index.js lib/buckets/creat.js lib/buckets/update.js lib/buckets/common.js lib/buckets/del.js lib/buckets/get.js lib/buckets/list.js lib/pg.js lib/ping.js lib/index.js lib/standalone.js lib/objects/reindex.js lib/objects/del.js lib/objects/get.js lib/objects/batch.js lib/objects/del_many.js lib/objects/index.js lib/objects/put.js lib/objects/update.js lib/objects/common.js lib/objects/find.js lib/server.js lib/errors.js lib/dtrace.js lib/types.js

   21:1  error  Parsing error: The keyword 'const' is reserved
 
 ✖ 1 problem (1 error, 0 warnings)
 
 tools/mk/Makefile.targ:201: recipe for target 'check-eslint' failed
 gmake: *** [check-eslint] Error 1
literal string using double-quote instead of single

comma or semicolon followed by non-blank
literal string using double-quote instead of single
Was there a reason you changed these to use self.client.query() instead of the self.query() method? We wrap the client's query so that we can get DTrace probes.
it is part of the hack-damage, I'm trying to clean this stuff up a bit before I head out for a week. Thanks for pointing this particular damage out!
indent by tabs instead of spaces
warning: identifer state hides an identifier in a parent scope
warning: identifer state hides an identifier in a parent scope
This "db" is unused since it's duplicated by the other key below. We should remove it.
Let's initialize this.handle to null here so that all fields are present in the constructor.

We should make sure to also call at the end of the PGClient constructor:

    EventEmitter.call(this);
Can we set this to null instead?

I think that it would be good to call out that the problem is that the "error" event that we've just handled has been called synchronously. Something like:

    /*
     * node-postgres's client.query() will fire "error" synchronously, 
     * resulting in this handler firing in the same tick as the client.query()
     * call. Since the PGClient.query() caller won't have had an opportunity to
     * set up their own "error" listener, we delay firing the event until the
     * next tick.
     */

You can write this as:

    setImmediate(done, 'error', err);
I'd be fine just renaming the method to destroy if .close() is no longer needed. It looks like the only consumer of that method was pgDestroy().

So, now that we're constructing the PGClient before this line runs, this will remove the "error" listener that PGClient adds, which we want to keep. We should probably move the onError function below towards the top of the _pgCreate() function body, so that we can make this line instead:

    client.removeListener('error', onError);

When using Moray standalone mode, the URL can be a path to a Unix domain socket, in which case there's no host or port. I think we can just get rid of the pg_url_parse(), and pass dummy values here, since the custom resolver isn't ever going to make use them.
Does this merit an explanatory comment? I know there's one in the PGPool `checkout` method, but I would be inclined to look at the constructor for information on its members.
I think I added this here based on earlier feedback. I agree that a comment belongs here too. thanks!
Why are we emitting an 'updated' event here? Does the cueball connection pool listen to this event?

I was using CueBallResolver as a reference; but it looks like no one listens for this ? that seems odd (if no one listens for it, and we emit it here, that would cause an exception -- I don't recall seeing that in my testing).

Anyhow, it seems pretty clear that it doesn't belong here. Thanks!
Really not a big deal, but we could make this a new sentence. Right now it reads like a run-on. Could we mention what the "handle" points to here?
